title.page0: Exploring the habitat of a stream
title.page2: Stream habitats: RIFFLE, POOL, and RUN

intro.description: Learn about exploring habitats and discover the diverse riparian ecosystems and land use activities along rivers.

page1.introText: Rivers and their surroundings have been used by people since ancient times for many different activities, such as farming, building homes, fishing, traveling, and getting water. This land use shows how humans interact with and shape the areas around rivers.
page1.instruction: Look carefully at the both illustration and choose which
page1.quizQuestion: From the list below, click on the activities you can see in the pictures:

page2.instruction: Read the definitions of the terms
page2.instructionEnd: below, then drag and drop each label to its correct place in the two images.

definitions.POOL: A deeper, slower-moving section of a stream where water collects. Pools are quiet, calm, and provide shelter for fish.
definitions.RIFFLE: A shallow, fast-flowing part of a stream with small waves and visible rocks. Riffles appear rough and bubbly, and are rich in oxygen, making them ideal habitats for insects and fish.
definitions.RUN: A smooth, moderately deep section of a stream where water flows steadily between a riffle and a pool. Runs get plenty of sunlight, which helps algae grow. Insects feed on the algae, making runs good feeding spots for fish from pools and riffles.

quizOptions.flood-protection: Flood protection structures (dikes, embankments and bridges)
quizOptions.pastures: Pastures and grazing areas for livestock
quizOptions.riparian-vegetation: Riparian vegetation (trees and shrubs along the riverbanks)

title.page1: Flood control function â€“ Floodplains like a sponge

intro.description: Learn about flood control functions and discover how floodplains act as natural sponges that absorb and store water.

page1.instruction: Hover over different areas of the images to reveal useful facts.

left.willows-banks: Willows stabilize banks and increase soil porosity through extensive root systems.
left.reed-vegetation: Dense reed vegetation slows water flow, traps sediments, and improves water quality.
left.native-grasses: Native grasses improve soil porosity and water infiltration
left.leaf-litter: Leaf litter on the forest floor retains moisture and reduces surface runoff.
left.deep-rooted-trees: Deep-rooted trees and shrubs offer stronger bank stabilization than shallow-rooted grasses.

right.natural-filtration: The river is confined by dikes like a tight corset.  It can't spread out or reach the floodplain, so floodwaters rise quickly
right.ecosystem-benefits: Without riverside plants, there's nothing to slow down runoff or absorb water. The soil becomes cracked and compactedâ€”water can't soak in.
right.groundwater-recharge: Without plants along the banks, runoff flows faster, more sediments and nutrients enter the river, and water quality declines

left.title: Did you know?
items: Floodplain soils store 3,000-4,000 mÂ³ of water per hectare
Floodplain vegetation stores 30-40% of total retention capacity
Natural floodplain absorbs floodwater for 20-30 days
Groundwater recharge: 500-1,000 mÂ³ per hectare per year

right.title: Did you know?
items: Loss of vegetation decreases capacity by: 40-50%
Degraded floodplain retains only: 1,000-2,000 mÂ³ per hectare

page2.instruction: Can you spot the missing floodplain superpowers? Match the description numbers to the healthy floodplain (left) and degraded floodplain (right).

left: A meandering river flows in gentle curves, spreading water across the floodplain, slowing flow, and nourishing the land.
Plants along riverbanks slow runoff, trap sediments, and absorb excess nutrients, helping to keep the water clean.
Floodplain lakes and oxbows store excess floodwater, support rich biodiversity, and help recharge groundwater
right: In heavy rain, floods can build up, break dikes, and threaten nearby villages.
In a straightened, channelized river, faster flow causes erosion and riverbed deepening, which dries out nearby floodplains
Without riverside plants, there's nothing to slow down runoff or absorb water.

subtitle.page3: C. Restoring floodplains as a Nature-based Solution

intro.description: Explore how people rely on floodplains and aquatic ecosystems, and discover pathways to restore their benefits for communities and nature.

activity1.title: Activity 1
activity1.description: Look closelyâ€”this is how human actions have transformed the Danube and its floodplains. Dikes, farming, navigation, and other pressures changed the landscape.
activity1.question: Can you help me by matching each pressure label to the right place in the picture?
activity1.instruction: People cleared forests, transformed the floodplains into pastures and crop fields, and built villages and later cities near the banks of the Danube. To protect themselves from floods, they constructed dikes. The Danube was also developed as a navigational waterway and for hydropower production. As a result, the river lost many of its natural features: the balance of sediments in the riverbed was disturbed, and the connection between the river channel and its floodplains was largely cut off. Only a few remnants of the original floodplain remained, while many typical animals and plants disappeared.

activity2.title: Activity 2
activity2.description: To solve societal problems with this Nature-based Solution, you can now explore suitable restoration measures: each picture shows one way how people and nature may work together.
activity2.question: At the bottom, you will find a list with six measures. Can you match the number of the measure from the list with the respective image that shows it?
activity2.instruction: Step by step, parts of the Danube floodplain are being reconnected to the river. Old side arms are reopened, forests and wetlands are restored, and natural flooding is allowed again wherever possible. These measures bring back habitats for fish, birds, and plants, while also helping people â€” by storing floodwaters, improving water quality, providing water during droughts, and offering space for recreation. These restoration Measures are called Nature-based Solution.

activity3.title: Activity 3
activity3.description: These polar charts show how the Danube's ecosystem services change in three different scenarios: natural floodplains, altered floodplains with human pressures, and restored floodplains with nature-based solutions. Can you find out why the services look so different?

column1.title: Original natural Floodplain
column1.question: Looking at this polar chart, why are almost all ecosystem services very high, while agriculture is low?

options.A: Because the soil in the floodplain was too poor and nothing could grow there.
options.B: Because farming was forbidden by the rulers of the Danube region in those times.
options.C: Because the floodplain was still natural, offering many benefits for people and animals, but farming was not possible on flooded land.

column2.title: Altered floodplain
column2.question: Why is agricultural production so much provided in this status, while most other services are low?

options.A: Because the Danube's natural forests and wetlands expanded, increasing farming and timber production at the same time.
options.B: Because dikes disconnected the floodplain from the river, protecting agriculture from floods but destroying many natural habitats and their benefits.
options.C: Because no one lived near the Danube, so only a few services were used.

column3.title: Restored floodplain
column3.question: Why are the ecosystem services more balanced in this polar chart compared to the other two?

options.A: Because nature-based solutions restore side arms, wetlands, and forests, which bring back multiple benefits for both nature and people.
options.B: Because people allowed the river to flood naturally, and removed all the pressures
options.C: Because the Danube was cut off from its floodplains by dikes.

cutting-meanders.label: Cutting meanders
cutting-meanders.description: Straightening the river (making the river shorter and straighter instead of meandering)

building-dikes.label: Building dikes
building-dikes.description: Flood protection dikes (raised embankments along the river that keep the water inside the main channel and stop it from reaching the floodplain)

channellizing-rivers.label: Channellizing rivers
channellizing-rivers.description: Channelizing the river (protecting the banks of straightened rivers from erosion by covering them by stones, or by building groynes [small transverse stone barriers] so the river cannot change its river bed any more)

draining-floodplains.label: Draining floodplains
draining-floodplains.description: Drying out wetlands (removing water from wetlands to make land usable for pastures, crop fields and settlements)

urbanization.label: Urbanization
urbanization.description: Building settlements, roads, and cities, accompanied by wastewater discharge into the river.

agriculture-pesticides.label: Agriculture using pesticides, insecticides, etc.
agriculture-pesticides.description: Application of chemicals in farming against weeds and insects

industrialization.label: Industrialization
industrialization.description: Building factories and industries, often accompanied by air, soil or water pollution

dams-hydroelectric.label: Dams, hydroelectric power plants, etc.
dams-hydroelectric.description: Construction of river barriers (transverse concrete structures that stop water, sediment and fish from moving freely)

invasive-species.label: Invasive species
invasive-species.description: Newcomer species (plants or animals from other continents that spread massively and cause problems by their dominance)

navigation.label: Navigation
navigation.description: Ships and canals (deepening and regulating rivers so big ships can travel along them)

climate-change.label: Climate change
climate-change.description: Global warming (more extreme weather conditions caused by humans)

restoration-sidearms.label: Restoration of river side-arms
restoration-sidearms.description: Re-opening old river branches so that water can flow there again, creating multiple habitats for fish, birds, and plants.

dike-relocation.label: Dike relocation for more space
dike-relocation.description: Moving dikes further away from the river to provide more space to the river and floodplain forests that may retain flood waters.

buffer-strips.label: Buffer strips
buffer-strips.description: Restoring narrow forests between agricultural fields and rivers so they can filter nutrients and hence protect water from pollution.

fish-ramps.label: Fish ramps or remove barriers
fish-ramps.description: Helping fish migrate by removing barriers or transforming them into ramps of stones enabling them to swim upstream again.

bypass-channels.label: Bypass channels
bypass-channels.description: Creating artificial side channels around barriers with gentle slopes where fish and other animals can move, or even live.

native-species.label: Support native species
native-species.description: Restoring natural habitat conditions to support native plants and animals, making it harder for invasive species to spread.

title.page1: Nature's final filter â€“ The Treatment Wetland
title.page2: Layer by layer â€“ Nature's cleaning crew
title.page3: Let's build nature's filter - Vertical Flow Wetland

intro.description: Learn about treatment wetlands and discover how constructed wetlands naturally filter and clean wastewater.

tooltip.first: I'm Rocky the Drainer! I collect the cleaned water and let it flow out safely to the river. I keep the bottom open and full of air so the whole system can breathe.
tooltip.second: Function: Collects the cleaned water, ensures aeration from below, and directs flow to the outlet.

tooltip.first: I'm Reeda, Flowkeeper! My roots keep the filter open so the water can pass through easily. I protect the wetland from heat and cold, bring in a bit of oxygen, and give microbes a good place to live.
tooltip.second: Function: Root growth maintains hydraulic conductivity of the filter, provide insulation against heat (summer) and cold (winter), slows down inflow, supports microbes, and takes up some nutrients.

tooltip.first: Hey there! I'm Gravelia the Distributor! I stop fine particles from blocking the bottom and spread the water evenly.  I keep everything balanced between Sandy above and Rocky below.
tooltip.second: Function: Distributes water evenly, prevents clogging, and protects the drainage zone below.

tooltip.first: I'm Sandy the Cleaner! Millions of microbes live between my grains â€” they eat waste and transform nitrogen and organic matter into harmless forms. I do most of the real cleaning work here!
tooltip.second: Function: Hosts microbial biofilms that perform most of the biological cleaning (nitrification, organic matter removal, some phosphorus binding). Fine texture slows water for longer contact time â†’ better cleaning.
tooltip.highlightText: perform most of the biological cleaning

page2.instruction:

Pour the materials from the buckets in the correct order to build your vertical treatment wetland â€” first stones, then gravel, sand, and finally plant the reeds on top.

page4.intro: Now that the wetland is built, let's meet its hidden workers â€” the tiny microbes who do most of the cleaning job.
page4.conclusion: Thanks to millions of tiny helpers like Nino, Dina, Phos, and Bacto, the water leaves the treatment wetland fresh and clean â€” ready to flow back to Danubius and start its journey again!

title.page3: Additional retention of nitrogen by floodplains
title.page6: Additional retention of phosphorous by floodplains

intro.description: Learn about self purification functions and discover how rivers and floodplains naturally filter and clean water.

nutrients1.area1: Pollution that comes from many scattered places, such as farm fields, roads, or towns, and is carried into rivers by rain or runoff.
nutrients1.area2: Pollution that comes from a single, identifiable place, such as a pipe from a factory or a wastewater treatment plant.
nutrients1.area3: Fertilizers and manure dissolve in rainwater and move through the soil or across fields into rivers. This is the main source of diffuse nitrogen pollution.
nutrients1.area4: Rainwater carries nitrogen compounds from streets, vehicles, and urban green areas into drains and rivers.
nutrients1.area5: Treated water still contains some nitrogen compounds that flow into rivers through outlet pipes. In some countries, modern plants remove most nitrogen efficiently, but in others, treatment is less advanced â€” or even missing.
nutrients1.area6: Some factories release nitrogen-rich wastewater from food processing, chemicals, or manufacturing activities. Usually regulated but still important locally.

nutrients2.area1: Particulate N settles in sediments. Organic nitrogen particles sink down, and thus become accessible for microbes living between sand grains â€” quiet zones of purification.
nutrients2.area2: Nutrients â†’ Biomass (temporary). Algae and aquatic plants take up nitrate and ammonium; nitrogen is stored in their tissues until they decay.
nutrients2.area3: Ammonium â†’ Nitrate (needs oxygen). Tiny microbes in oxygen-rich sediments convert ammonium into nitrate â€” the first step of purification.
nutrients2.area4: Nitrate â†’ Nitrogen gas (no oxygen) Bacteria in low-oxygen zones turn nitrate into nitrogen gas â€” the key process for nitrogen loss.

nutrients3.area1: Nitrogen bound to particles settles. During floods, suspended particles with nitrogen are trapped and deposited on the floodplain surface.
nutrients3.area2: Nutrients â†’ Biomass (temporary). Floodplain plants absorb nitrogen during the growing season and store it in wood and leaves.
nutrients3.area3: Nitrate â†’ Nitrogen gas (no oxygen). In flooded soils, microbes breathe without oxygen and transform nitrate into nitrogen gas â€” permanent nitrogen removal.

nutrients4.area1: Pollution that comes from many scattered places, such as farmland, unpaved roads, or towns.
nutrients4.area2: Rainwater carries dust, detergents, and waste particles rich in phosphorus into drains and rivers.
nutrients4.area3: Phosphorus bound to soil particles is washed into rivers during rain or floods.
nutrients4.area4: Fertilizer phosphorus dissolves in water and slowly reaches rivers through the soil or overland flow. A smaller but steady diffuse source.
nutrients4.area5: Rainwater carries dust, detergents, and waste particles rich in phosphorus into drains and rivers.
nutrients4.area6: Even after treatment, part of the phosphorus remains in discharged water. Many countries have upgraded their plants, but others still lack efficient systems or any wastewater treatment at all.
nutrients4.area7: Certain factories release phosphorus-containing wastewater from cleaning, processing, or production activities. Usually regulated but still significant in some areas.

nutrients5.area1: Dissolved phosphate sticks to minerals such as iron, aluminium, or lime. When oxygen is present, phosphorus stays bound; but if oxygen is missing, it can be released again back into the water.
nutrients5.area2: Algae, aquatic plants, and biofilms take up phosphorus and use it for growth. This retention is temporary â€” when the organisms die or decay, the phosphorus is released to the water.
nutrients5.area3: Phosphorus attached to soil and organic particles sinks down to the riverbed. This happens mainly in calm areas or where the flow is slow â€” forming a temporary "phosphorus storage" in the sediment.

nutrients6.area1: When floodwaters spread across the land, they slow down and drop suspended particles rich in phosphorus. This is one of the most effective ways floodplains trap and store phosphorus.
nutrients6.area2: Floodplain plants absorb phosphorus as they grow, storing it in leaves and roots. This retention is temporary, but some phosphorus stays longer in litter and humus after plants die.
nutrients6.area3: Dissolved phosphorus binds to iron, aluminium, or calcium compounds in the soil. This keeps phosphorus locked away â€” unless oxygen runs out, when it can be released again.

quizModal.content: About 40% of phosphorus released into the Danube Basin never reaches the river mouth â€” it settles and is trapped in reservoirs and floodplains along the way.

section1.title: What Are Cookies?
section1.content: Cookies are small text files that are placed on your device when you visit a website. They are widely used to make websites work more efficiently and to provide information to the website owners.

section2.title: Types of Cookies We Use
section2.weDoNotUse: We do not use necessary/essential cookies or functional cookies.
section2.importantContent: All cookies used on this website require your consent. No cookies are placed without your explicit permission.

section3.title: Analytical Cookies (Google Analytics)
section3.intro: We use Google Analytics to understand how visitors interact with our website. These cookies help us collect information about:
infoItems: Number of visitors to the website
Which pages are viewed most frequently
How long visitors stay on the website
How visitors navigate through the website
section3.purposeContent: These cookies help us improve the website's functionality and user experience.
section3.consentRequiredContent: Yes - these cookies are only placed if you accept them via the cookie banner.
section3.dataCollectedContent: All data is anonymous and aggregated. We cannot identify individual users.

section4.title: Specific Cookies Used
section4.intro: The following cookies are set by Google Analytics (only if you have accepted cookies):
section4.noteContent: These cookies are set by Google Analytics and are subject to Google's privacy policy. We have configured Google Analytics with privacy-friendly settings including IP anonymization and disabled Google Signals and Ad Personalization.

section5.title: Managing Your Cookie Preferences
section5.intro: You have full control over cookies on this website:

preferences.label: Accept or Reject:
preferences.content: When you first visit the website, you can accept or reject analytical cookies via the cookie banner at the bottom of the page.

preferences.label: Change your preference:
preferences.content: You can change your cookie preferences at any time by clearing your browser cookies and revisiting the website. The cookie banner will appear again allowing you to make a new choice.

preferences.label: Browser settings:
preferences.content: You can also manage cookies directly in your browser settings. Most browsers allow you to block or delete cookies. Please note that blocking cookies may affect your experience on some websites.

section6.title: Third-Party Cookies
section6.content: Google Analytics cookies are technically third-party cookies (set by Google), but they are used solely for our website analytics. We do not use any other third-party cookies for advertising, social media, or other purposes.
